anybody know if is there are Java collection class that has a method for just popping the last item off the collection?
hmm, Stack?
Stack is one of those do-not-use classes
shit.. I was bout to say, me wonders if Stack is deprecated.. most of the obviously useful and simple Java classes are deprecated and replaced by something more complex and opaque
Do you have to support Java <6?
Dashiva: so what do the Java gods mandate that I use instead?
Dashiva: no, I think Java 6-only is OK
ArrayDeque is great if not
checks ArrayDeque doc
Dashiva: but, really, is the whole Java-let's-deprecate-everything phenomenon some kind of absurdist joke or something?
It's not deprecation for no reason
It's because the old container classes were pre-generics
oh
Also, lots of them were sychronized
I see
Spelled correctly, anyhow
I guess it's just that every time I find something that intuitively maps to my use cases and programming experiences, I find that's in deprecated
The good names were taken first, of course :)
yeah
That's not to say you can't use the old classes, they still work. But they're deprecated because the alternatives are generally better.

and make everybody stumble

train drivers should be wired to get an electric shock every time they do that
this it Odakyu sen
the only thing worse than JR
heh
as long as they stay on the rails I’m happy
I'd rather they also tried harder to arrive on time
Odakyu is the online train line I've seen in Japan that can't manage to get trains to run on time
and plus every time it rains, all hell seems to break lose
maybe they’re using the British Rail model
leaves on the track! oh noes!

the other day when it was raining here, they announced "We've had an accident on the ENoshima line, so we will not go all the way to Shonandai (my station), instead we will stop at Sagami Ono".. so, fuck you
basically
there are no other train lines that connect to Sagami Ono
and they gave no info about, if you need to get further down to Fujisawa or whatever, this is what you should to
*do
that’s … helpful
instead, it was just "get off the train and don't let the doors hit you in the ass on the way out"
(for taxi companies)

heh
boblet: you have made yourself a member of the cabal, for better or worse

wow, sweet! looking forward to those holographic member ids you told me about
the one with hypno-powers
now, when people bitch about the "HTML clusterfuck" and the people responsible, you can count yourself among the privileged few they have in mind
rock! … umm I think
so boblet
if you can indulge me
I have something to share
I went to the supermarket this morning
I’m always down for your indulgences
to buy some english muffins
mm muffins
I got to the store and found that they had two brands of english muffins
and they looked a lot the same
and were the same price
so I'm confronted with a dilemma
how do I choose?
what process do I use to decide
elementary. buy one of each and have a taste-off
I considered the options available to me
don’t thank me, thank science
I could, say, try to get some expert advice from the management
heh
good luck with that
well, I could even do a lifeline call to a english-muffin expert somewhere
or I could attempt to do some detailed analysis there myself, at the stor
close examination
I mean, I could have spent all day there at the store deciding what english muffins to buy
and agonizing and hand-wringing over whether I was making the right decision
because, you know, I had to make *some* decision
I needed english muffins
obviously
I had an english-muffing consumer market waiting at home to consume some english muffins
and I thought, I have a risk here of making the wrong decision
and alienating my english-muffin consumer market at home
I stand by my scientific experiment suggestion (which would also ensure seconds for your aforementioned consumer market), but other variables worthy of evaluation are
having them tell me, boy, Mikey, you sure really fucked up that english-muffin-buying decision
"what a mess you made of the english-muffin-buying task that you were given responsibility for"
etc.
anyway, you know the punchline
weight, relative springiness, length of ingredients list, relative average length of ingredients in ingredients list (in both cases shorter=better), and due-by date
the other option is to just lie and say that’s all they had
well, after 10 seconds of agonized though about it, I just grabbed one and took it the counter and paid
and I got back in time to ship the code
er, I mean I got back in time to have breakfast
anyway, it would be a mistake for anybody to read too much into this little story
I just felt like sharing
damn you and your finely crafted metaphors
"get a decision made in time to actually eat breakfast"
don’t forget that it’s entirely possible you would still have got into trouble for choosing the wrong muffin, for no apparent reasons (consumer markets can be unforgiving in the morning)
yeah, the damned-if-you-do-or-damned-if-you-don'tness of life
Huck Finn wrote about that
well, Mark Twain did
I think Huck's conclusion was, I guess I'll just be damned.
but he got Jim out to safety
and he had a pretty good time along the way doing it
and he learned a lot
“just be damned” that’d make a good quote for the IRC logs header
Huck shipped the code

legal in DTDs?
another ban: if you intend your spec to end up the web browser vendors must be involved; if they're not and you continue ahead anyway you lose the right to complain later on
I'm trying hard to un-learn anything I ever knew about DTDs
annevk: amen
again, seriously
groups of mad scientists off quietly spending years in their remote labs developing Frankenstein monsters
then unleashing them on the world and asking that they be welcomed with open arms
hsivonen: i think so, although the html4 dtd usually sets a default value instead of #IMPLIED for enumerated attributes that aren't booleans
method      (GET|POST)     GET
checked     (checked)      #IMPLIED

hi all
hi

(unless I am missing something)
notes 15.3.1.1 in es5
zcorpan_: That's not relevant
zcorpan_: That's only relevant for the Function object
As in what is bound to "Function" in the global scope be default
wonders if any work on WebIDL is actually happening
so for xhr it seems firefox and opera return an object while safari and chrome throw TypeError
TypeError is what I would expect given the spec
But I don't really trust the spec :)
although typeof XMLHttpRequest == 'function'
That's expected
It's just the difference between [[call]] and [[construct]], so even if it only implements [[construct]] I'd expect that to be true
ok
zcorpan_, I don't get that twitter message
annevk: then we're two
though I've heard the sentiment about not bundling codecs before and "letting the market decide" but I don't really buy that either
It is kindof supposed to be an invariant of the language that typeof x === "function" <=> x implements [[call]]
Although regexp objects break that (in some implementations?)
I think everything with [Constructor] should not have [[call]]
annevk: That would require a change to ECMAScript
e.g. x = Image() rather than x = new Image() is wrong imo
Oh I see
Well all the builtins already work like that
with the same semantics?
Yeah
I thought there was some difference
maybe I should decide not to care and let someone else figure it out
Actually taht's not quite true
it is true for Array
But not for String
String(a) cocerces a to a string primitive, new String(a) coerces a to a string primitive and wraps that primitive in a string object
(the language bug here is that String objects exist)
zcorpan_: ah. shows how little I remember about DTDs. I didn't remember that enumerated tokens don't need to be quoted
Date is also weird
Date() returns a string new Date() returns a Date object
has anybody here reviewed and/or commented on http://www.w3.org/2006/WSC/drafts/rec/rewrite.html
Web Security Context: User Interface Guidelines

So basically ES follows [[Call]] === [[Construct]] except for String, Number, Boolean (none of which should exist), Date (which is a mess) and RegExp in the case where the first argument is a preexisting regexp object

erlehmann

error message: "Content contains the character sequence \u201c<!--\u201d without a later occurrence of the character sequence \u201c-->\u201d."
and another is "Content contains the character sequence "<script>" without a later occurrence of the character sequence "</script>"
hmm, does opera even have a public bug tracker ?
erlehmann: The public can submit bugs
Just not actually be informed of any progress on them.
Opera now officially has the least open bug tracker of any browser vendor.
Sounds like lots of dupes.
I whine at the Opera employees here about it sometimes, but they haven't managed to get it fixed yet.
AryehGregor: Opinions on the merits of this vary
erlehmann, what, as opposed to the public bug trackers where half the bugs filed *aren't* dupes?  :)
anyone with opera can check if http://blog.dieweltistgarnichtso.net/podcast-podcasts-feat-sikk plays now ? i am on throttled UMTS
jgraham, yes, yes, I know.  I'll continue to make fun of you as long as you're more secretive than Microsoft, though.
Microsoft has a secretive bug tracker
They just have a public one in addition to it
So that's less secretive than Opera, then.
but I don't think that makes it clear which is most secretive overall
Which has only a secret bug tracker.
Opera has forums and blog posts where people complain about bugs
I imagine Apple also has a secret bug tracker for tracking non-WebKit Safari issues, unless that's also public?
which are basically public bug trackers
(just without any good bug tracking features)
No, because you don't get told what the status is.
If we did get a public bug tracker I imagine it would be disconnected from our internal one
I mean, by that argument, me complaining to jgraham on IRC is a public bug tracker.
Apple has rdar
or whatever it is called
doesn't touch anything manufactured by Apple with a ten-foot pole, so doesn't have reason to know
Complaining on IRC is not like filing bugs. On the other hand I personally have looked through the desktop blog comments for useful bug reports
The signal to noise is pretty low though (at least for the bugs that I care about rather than "this UI element is 2px off from where I would ideally like it")
(which might be bugs that someone else cares about)
Signal-to-noise drops drastically as you make the bug tracker more accessible.  This is inevitable.
But it makes an influential subset of users (the more techy people, who care most about the difference between browsers and understand them best) feel better.
AryehGregor: Sure. I understand all the arguments for public bug trackers
And I understand all the ones for private bug trackers.

However, I operate on the theory that there is some level of persistent whining that will maximize people's chances of agreeing with you, and informal observational evidence suggests to me that this optimal level is nonzero.
AryehGregor: Well in your case you are whining at the wrong people :)

So I mention it occasionally when it comes up, to increase Opera employees' exposure to discontent about the status quo and bias them toward supporting a public bug tracker the next time it comes up internally.
Oh well.
Worth a try.
If all else fails, whining is fun anyway.

cannot be expected to conduct meaningful analysis on who the best person to whine at is in an organization whose internal structure is opaque, so just goes with the theory that everyone is responsible for everything.

AryehGregor: I guess it is typically the case that the people working the most in public are not the ones arguning for more closedness. So anyone you can find to whine to is unlikely to be the right person to whine to.
A good point.
I'll be sure to only mock Opera for fun from now on, with no intent of accomplishing any useful goals.
What is the current state of browser support for <datagrid>s?
Wasn't datagrid removed for now?
That would be annoying, it's the capability I'm most looking forward to.
Where would I find out if it had been removed?
It has been.
Months ago.
Not enough implementation, I think, or not enough interest, or too complicated, or some combination of the foregoing.
My impression was it would return in some future version, but it was thought best to concentrate on other things for this round.
(i.e., the next few years)
Yeah, too much work remaining on more basic elements
curses quietly.
Oh well, thanks for the info.
All the important apps are being ported: http://html5zombo.com/
I spent an hour with that playing in the background the other day.  It's strangely soothing.
